Title: STATE-BY-STATE News from across the USA
Full Text:
urn:contentItem:5J3X-RBP1-JC8N-K10B-00000-00STATE-BY-STATE2016-02-16T00:00:00Z2025-06-22T20:29:22ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 4ASTATE-BY-STATENews from across the USA

Alabama Decatur: Coyote sightings have increased during the breeding season. Cats are a main food source for the predators, especially at this time of year, the Decatur Daily reported.

Alaska Fairbanks: Residents have shown support for a U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service proposal that would ban some bear, wolf and coyote hunts on federal wildlife refuges, The Fairbanks Daily News-Miner reported.

Arizona Phoenix: HonorHealth John C. Lincoln Medical Center offered free hepatitis and HIV testing to patients after discovering a former employee was accused of stealing pain medication at a Colorado facility, The Arizona Republic reported.

Arkansas Fayetteville: State Rep. Micah Neal wants to levy property taxes on public colleges and universities for property they rent to commercial businesses or use for a "non-public purpose," the Northwest Arkansas Democrat-Gazette reported.

California San Diego: Witnesses rescued three men after a car plunged into Mission Bay, the San Diego Union-Tribune reported.

Colorado Denver: The police officer memorial at Denver police headquarters was vandalized, authorities said. The memorial was previously vandalized a year ago, KUSA-TV reported.

Connecticut Sprague: Federal officials will inspect wastewater lagoons at a former cardboard recycling plant here, The Day reported. The Environmental Protection Agency will assess the former site of Fusion Paperboard this spring.

Delaware Wilmington: Delaware gun purchases surged in December and January -- an increase fueled by non-traditional gun owners seeking protection, firearm sellers and advocates say. A total of 12,556 federal background checks were conducted for people buying guns in the state during the previous two months, according to data from the FBI -- a 26% jump over December 2014 to January 2015, The News Journal reported.

District of Columbia: Charles Young, a former assistant track coach at Dunbar Senior High School, pleaded guilty to sexually abusing seven male students.

Florida Palm Bay: The Space Coast Country music festival, planned for Feb.19-21 to replace the Runaway Country Music Festival, has been canceled, Florida Today reported.

Georgia College Park: A man died after being ejected from his truck during a police pursuit. Deputies with the Fulton County Sheriff's Office attempted to pull Jonathan Fowler, 32, over for speeding.

Hawaii Pearl Harbor: Hawaiian monk seals are doing better than researchers had previously thought, HawaiiNewsNow reported. Thanks to increased efforts by the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration researchers, the estimated population of monk seals in the main Hawaiian Islands is 1,272. It was previously thought to be around 1,100.

Idaho Pocatello: Bones from three types of meat-eating dinosaurs are coming to the Idaho State University Museum of Natural History, the Idaho State Journal reported.

Illinois Chicago: Mayor Rahm Emanuel's administration resurrected the idea of an express train to whisk business travelers and tourists between downtown and O'Hare International Airport, the Chicago Tribune reported. Fares would range from $25 to $35 for the roughly 20-minute journey, which is half the time it takes for the city's Blue Line "L'' trains.

Indiana West Lafayette: A staffer at Purdue University submitted his resignation after coming under fire for social media comments that groups that oppose abortion took as rape threats, the Journal and Courier reported. Students, parents and alumni had been pressing the university to sanction Jamie Newman, an accompanist at Purdue's Division of Dance, for his comments.

Iowa Iowa City: City staff is nearing completion of a draft ordinance intended to shape future growth and create more affordable housing stock in the growing Riverfront Crossings District, the Iowa City Press-Citizen reported.

Kansas Bonner Springs: Two Oklahoma men died in a single-vehicle crash here, The Kansas City Star reported.

Kentucky Louisville: The "International Honor Quilt," a collaborative feminist art project initiated by artist Judy Chicago, is on display at the University of Louisville through March 19, The Courier-Journal reported.

Louisiana Norco: A train trestle fire west of New Orleans disrupted Amtrak passenger train service.

Maine Augusta: State officials are offering scholarship grants to students pursuing an education in farming. The deadline for applications is March 1.

Maryland Edgewater: Anne Arundel County police say a husband and wife are dead following a three-vehicle crash on Valentine's Day south of here.

Massachusetts Lowell: A 15-year-old bicyclist was sent to the hospital with serious injuries after being hit by a vehicle that then fled the scene, authorities say.

Michigan Portland: Portland United Methodist Church will have services Sunday after its 102-year-old building was damaged in a June tornado, the Lansing State Journal reported.

Minnesota St. Paul: Chris Lollie, 30, settled his lawsuit that he filed after police used a stun gun while arresting him in St. Paul's skyway system in 2014, the Star Tribune reported.

Mississippi Moss Point: Authorities say a wildfire has burned more than 3,000 acres in a national wildlife refuge in south Mississippi, The Sun Herald reported. The fire began near a few homes in a remote area of south Jackson County, then moved into the Grand Bay National Wildlife Refuge.

Missouri Kansas City: Anna Kurzweil, who died at the age of 100, donated $2million to the Society of Jesus, a Catholic order known as Jesuits upon her death in September 2012, The Kansas City Star reported. She worked as a teacher and lived on a pension.

Montana Columbia Falls: Shareholders approved the merger of timber companies Weyerhaeuser and Plum Creek, the Flathead Beacon reported. The Plum Creek company is based here.

NebraskaLincoln: A couple received a $641 water bill from the city because of the 100,000 gallons used by a running toilet.

NevadaLas Vegas: Police dog Nicky was hospitalized with stab wounds after she helped end a 12-hour standoff between authorities and a potentially armed man, KLAS-TV reported.

New Hampshire Concord: The state House killed a bill that would've legalized marijuana to those at least 21 years old and imposed a $15-per-ounce tax, the New Hampshire Union Leader reported.

New Jersey Rumson: Shannon Corsi's song, the sprite and tuneful piano ballad Trailblazer, was awarded third place in the MusiCares and Grammy Foundation's Teens Make Music songwriting competition, the Asbury Park Press reported. The competition called for musicians between 14 and 18 to submit a song that celebrates life "above the influence," or brings attention to the real-life consequences of substance abuse. Shannon is 17.

New Mexico Ohkay Owingeh: U.S. Sen. Martin Heinrich will tour area heroin treatment centers on Wednesday.

New York Putnam County: A county legislator wants the former first lady of the state to resign her tourism board post, The Journal News reported. Lawmakers in the county were unaware Libby Pataki was working for the taxpayer-financed non-profit Putnam County Visitors' Bureau and the private non-profit Putnam Tourism Corp.

North Carolina Raleigh: A North Carolina State University student spent 30 straight hours at a Waffle House after losing a bet. WTVD-TV reported that Mike Fuller spent 30 hours inside the restaurant after he came in last in his fantasy football league.

North Dakota Minot: A mental evaluation was ordered for Timothy Blowers, 21, who was accused of stealing an ambulance and crashing it near Carrington, KXMC-TV reported.

Ohio Dayton: The driver who drove the wrong way on Interstate 75 downtown and killed five, including himself, was jailed just over a day earlier on suspicion of drunken driving, the Dayton Daily News reported. Driver James Pohlabeln slammed into an SUV, and three members of local hard-rock band CounterFlux were among the deaths.

Oklahoma Chickasha: Grady County voters overwhelmingly approved a new quarter-cent sales tax that will go toward the construction of a new surgery center at Grady Memorial Hospital, The Oklahoman reported.

OregonPendleton: Local health officials say a virus spread by rodents has been diagnosed for the first time in a Umatilla County resident, the East Oregonian reported.

Pennsylvania Collegeville: Officials say the number of students at Ursinus College reporting symptoms of a stomach illness has now topped 200, according to The Philadelphia Inquirer.

Rhode Island Providence: State municipalities were awarded about $12.9million in federal funding for the upkeep and preservation of public housing.

South Carolina Camden: The Kershaw County Sheriff's Department charged Jimmy Joe Methe, 49, with voluntary manslaughter after killing Brandon Spencer, 17, on his property. Methe claimed the teen was stealing items from his truck, WLTX-TV reported. Officials said another person who fled the scene has not been identified. Investigators recovered items from the truck and found a gas can and hose they believe was used to siphon gas from Methe's truck.

South Dakota Rapid City: A new long-range plan for the local school district calls for the closure of some schools, the Rapid City Journal reported. District officials cautioned that the facilities improvement report commissioned by the school board, which includes an estimated $333million cost over 10 years, is not a firm blueprint for the district's future.

TennesseeLebanon: Cumberland University launched a major online project Monday -- in time for Presidents Day -- on the papers of Martin Van Buren at VanBurenPapers.org, university officials said. Van Buren, whose handwriting was notoriously illegible, was the eighth U.S. president, serving from 1837 to 1841.

Texas Austin: University of Texas researchers Lucy Hunt and Paul Eastwick say speed dating or video interaction is much more effective than posting a photo to an online profile when looking for love, the Austin American-Statesman reported.

Utah Salt Lake City: Utah's public schools need more teachers to fill their classrooms, but state colleges say young students are showing hardly any interest in the profession. Though undergraduate degrees from Utah colleges have grown 25% in the past decade, teaching diplomas have shown only a 5% increase in the same period, the Salt Lake Tribune reported.

Vermont Swanton: William Fournier, 23, was found dead on an iced-over Lake Champlain about 100 to 150 yards from his truck, which had sunk through the ice, Burlington Free Press reported. Police believe Fournier, who had been ice fishing with friends in the Campbell's Bay area Saturday, may have succumbed to hypothermia, but an autopsy will determine cause and manner of death, Swanton Sgt. Eugene Rich said.

Virginia Richmond: A man rescued a driver from a burning car after a serious wreck on Interstate 64 in Henrico County, the Richmond Times-Dispatch reported.

Washington Spokane: The Spokesman-Review reported that Avista is asking state regulators to approve a pilot program that would see 265 charging stations for electric cars in eastern Washington state. The company in a request filed last month with the Washington Utilities and Transportation Commission cites environmental benefits, fuel cost savings and vehicle performance as benefits of the plan.

West Virginia Fayetteville: Two people were killed in a house fire, The Register-Herald reported.

Wisconsin Madison: Poor water clarity led to a slow start for the 2016 sturgeon spearing season, as spearers harvested less than 350 fish on the Winnebago system over the weekend, the state Department of Natural Resources said.

Wyoming Cheyenne: A House committee advanced a bill that would require legislative approval before Wyoming could set up a refugee resettlement program, the Wyoming Tribune Eagle reported. The bill blocks the governor from unilaterally setting up a state program that would help refugees who arrive directly or indirectly in Wyoming.

Compiled by Tim Wendel, Nicole Gill and Jonathan Briggs, with Carolyn Cerbin, Linda Dono, Mike Gottschamer, Ben Sheffler, Mike B. Smith and Nichelle Smith. Design by Mallory Redinger. Graphics by Alejandro Gonzalez.

Title: Alan D. Schnitzer CEO of Travelers in top 11% of price performers of NYSE stocks in past week Tuesday August 16, 2022
Full Text:
urn:contentItem:665H-P6C1-JB4F-Y031-00000-00Alan D. Schnitzer CEO of Travelers in top 11% of price performers of NYSE stocks in past week Tuesday August 16, 20222022-08-16T00:00:00Z2025-06-22T20:29:30ZLexisNexisAlan D. Schnitzer CEO of Travelers in top 11% of price performers of NYSE stocks in past week Tuesday August 16, 2022

Alan D. Schnitzer's performance as Chief Executive Officer of Travelers (NYSE:TRV) is ranked in the top 11% of BuySellSignals performers for the past week; a percentile ranking of 88.5 out of 3,301 companies listed on the New York Stock Exchange. The present value of $1,000 invested on the appointment date of August 02, 2017 at close price of $114.46 is $1,702, including a capital gain of $504 and dividend reinvested of $198.

The Travelers Companies, Inc. (NYSE:TRV), NYSE's 10th largest Insurance company by market cap, has climbed $12.18 (or 7.6%) in the past week to close at $172.16.

Compared with the S&P 500 Index which rose 157.1 points (3.8%) in the week, the relative price increase was 3.8%.

In the past week the market cap has risen by $2.9 billion to $40.9 billion (USD41 billion).

Reinforcing Bullish Signals

- The present value of $1,000 (PV1000) invested 1 year ago is now worth $1,151 for a capital gain of $126 and dividend reinvested of $25. This corresponds to annualised shareholder returns of 15.1%.

- Rises for a second consecutive week: The stock rose for a second consecutive week on Monday bringing its two-week rise to $15.89 or 10.2%.

- Strengthens above MAP: The 200-day Moving Average Price (MAP) is $166.06, up from $165.81 a week ago. A rising MAP over the past week is a bullish signal. The price to MAP ratio is 1.04, up from 0.96 a week ago. A rising P/MAP ratio is another bullish signal.

- Above VWAP: The price is at a premium of 7.9% to the 1-month Volume Weighted Average Price (VWAP) of $159.54.

SECTION 1 BIOGRAPHY: ALAN D. SCHNITZER, CEO, CHAIRMAN AND DIRECTOR

Mr. Schnitzer, age 52, is Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of Travelers. He was previously the Company's Vice Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, Business and International Insurance from July 2014 to December 2015. He was Vice Chairman-Financial, Professional and International Insurance and Field Management; Chief Legal Officer from May 2012 until July 2014. Prior to that, he was Vice Chairman and Chief Legal Officer since joining the Company in April 2007 and Executive Vice President-Financial, Professional and International Insurance since May 2008. Prior to joining the Company, he was a partner at Simpson Thacher & Bartlett LLP.

Other Board Service

Mr. Schnitzer serves as a member of the Board of Trustees of the University of Pennsylvania, the Board of Overseers of the Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center and the Board of Directors of the Connecticut Council for Education Reform.

Nomination Considerations

The Board and the Nominating and Governance Committee considered in particular Mr. Schnitzer's position as Chairman and CEO of the Company and his significant experience in the management of the Company in various roles, including as Chief Executive Officer of Business and International Insurance, the Company's largest business segment, as well as his significant experience and expertise in management, finance and law.

SECTION 9 TRAVELERS: CORPORATE PROFILE

9.1 Travelers Activities

The Travelers Companies, Inc. (TRV) is a holding company principally engaged, through its subsidiaries, in providing a range of commercial, and personal property and casualty insurance products and services to businesses, government units, associations and individuals. The Company is organized in three business segments: Business Insurance; Financial, Professional & International Insurance, and Personal Insurance. The Business Insurance segment offers an array of property and casualty insurance and insurance-related services to its clients primarily in the United States. The Financial, Professional & International Insurance segment includes surety and financial liability coverages, which require a primarily credit-based underwriting process. Personal Insurance writes a range of property and casualty insurance covering personal risks. In December 2008, the Company completed the sale of Unionamerica Holdings Limited. It is the NYSE's 10th largest Insurance company by market capitalisation.

In FY 2021, the top earner of Revenue was Business Insurance [53.7%] followed by Personal Insurance [36.4%] at Rank 2 and Bond & Specialty Insurance [9.8%] at Rank 3. In FY 2021, revenue growth was highest in Bond & Specialty Insurance [11.3%] followed by Personal Insurance [10.7%] at Rank 2 and Business Insurance [6.3%] at Rank 3.

urn:contentItem:69S5-JW31-JBCN-33HG-00000-00STATE-BY-STATE2016-10-26T00:00:00Z2025-06-22T20:29:30ZLexisNexisUSA TODAYPg. Z4STATE-BY-STATENews from across the USA

ALABAMA Tuscaloosa: Officials are cracking down on temporary rentals, a practice they said proliferates during Alabama football season. The Tuscaloosa News reported the city is preparing to send out letters to people found advertising their homes for rent on sites such as Airbnb.

ALASKA Anchorage: People who find animals after hours but cannot take them home can leave them in heated night-drop kennels behind Anchorage Animal Care and Control, reported KTVA-TV. Shelter workers check the kennels every morning.

ARIZONA Flagstaff: The Forest Service began its reconstruction of a decades-old lookout tower that overlooks Flagstaff. Coconino National Forest officials said the work on the Mount Elden tower should be completed by April 30. ARKANSAS Bentonville: Fire and ambulance services across Northwest Arkansas said they desperately need emergency medical technicians, the Northwest Arkansas Democrat-Gazette reported.

CALIFORNIA Half Moon Bay: For the first time, the Titans of Mavericks big-wave surf contest will have a women’s heat, the Contra Costa Times reported. The heat will be a one-hour, six-woman contest with a $30,000 prize purse within the main event this season.

COLORADO Denver: Malala Yousafzai, who shared the 2014 Nobel Peace Prize, made a surprise visit to a Denver high school that offers special programs for refugee students, The Denver Post reported. The Pakistani children’s rights activist spoke at South High School.

CONNECTICUT Hartford:

Officials with the Travelers Championship golf tournament say this summer’s PGA event raised more than $2.8 million for charity. The tournament’s primary charitable beneficiary was the ALS Clinic at the Hospital for Special Care in New Britain, which treats 250 Connecticut ALS patients annually.

DELAWAREGeorgetown:

Authorities dropped child sex abuse charges against a 23-year-old Indian River School District employee and charged her accuser with making false statements to police. Georgetown police discovered Natanael Perez-Gonzalez was born in 1995, not 1998, as listed in school and immigration documents, so he was 20 years old when the incidents occurred.

DISTRICT OF COLUMBIA: WUSATV reported that the Vida Thrive 5K Run and Walk at Hains Point drew more than 600 participants and raised $16,000 for the city’s homeless.

FLORIDA Cocoa: The League of Women Voters announced a new program in which homeowners and businesses can join together to bring down the cost of solar panels by 20% or more, Florida Today reported.

GEORGIA Columbus: A third suspect in the shooting death of a 24-year-old father inside a Columbus mall earlier this year is in custody. Media outlets reported that Terrell McFarland, 25, was arrested last week.

HAWAII Maui: Fede Jaime, 36, was bitten by a shark while paddling on his surfboard off Hookipa Beach on Friday, Hawaii News Now reported. Jaime credits fellow surfers with saving his life by forming a protective shield around him and helping him paddle ashore.

IDAHO Richfield: Lincoln County Search and Rescue found a missing hunter, KMVTTV reported. Sgt. Andy McClure said the man was disoriented and thought he was walking toward his car but was walking in the opposite direction.

ILLINOIS Dennison: Officials said an Indiana State University freshman died after apparently falling from a boat into a small pond during a fraternity event in Illinois.

INDIANA Muncie: Alex Paul Estes, 26, was arrested on a preliminary charge of battery resulting in serious bodily injury for allegedly punching a man in the face outside a southside Marsh supermarket, The Star-Press reported.

IOWASioux City: Officials announced plans last week for a new downtown park after a local donor contributed $500,000 to the project, according to the Sioux City Journal. According to preliminary plans, Pearl Street Park will include green space, trees, a sensory garden, seating areas and tables.

KANSAS Wichita: Authorities were on the lookout for a woman who is accused of nearly hitting a group of mounted police officers. The Wichita Eagle reported that a collision was narrowly avoided when the woman exited a parking lot in the city’s Old Town district at a high rate of speed.

fort KENTUCKY : Kentucky Frank ’s - poet laureate, George Ella Lyon, is collecting poems from each of the state’s counties for her “Where I’m From”: A Poetry of Place work. The deadline to submit is Dec. 1.

LOUISIANA New Roads: Authorities said two people were hospitalized after a fire broke out at False River Manor Apartments, an assisted-living complex, in New Roads, WBRZTV reported.

P O

MAINE Presque Island: Maine’s annual moose hunt returned to the far northern part of the state for the last time this year. This year’s moose hunt is broken up into four sessions in different parts of the state. A portion of the hunt centered in the far north began Monday and ends Saturday.

MARYLAND Baltimore: Gov. Hogan said the state will reapply for federal funds to make room for double-stacked containers in Baltimore’s aged Howard Street Tunnel, officials said. Hogan and CSX Transportation Chairman and CEO Michael Ward reaffirmed their commitments to improvements needed to bring taller trains to the Port of Baltimore.

MASSACHUSETTS Pittsfield: A 36-year-old man who caused thousands of dollars’ worth of damage to a church during a break-in was sentenced to nine months in jail,

The Berkshire Eagle

reported.

Township MICHIGAN : Waterford The board of this township approved a resolution to stop participating in a federal resettlement program for Syrian refugees until security issues are addressed.

i F n i

s W s

h

MINNESOTA Minneapolis: A man who photographed Prince during the music superstar’s early years is suing a Minneapolis studio to recover about 3,000 original pictures. Allen Beaulieu’s federal lawsuit is against Studio 1124 and its owner, Clint Stockwell.

MISSISSIPPI Wiggins: MississippiNAACP President Derrick Johnson is demanding a federal investigation after the parents of a black high school student said four white students put a noose around their son’s

neck at school. He said the

incident happened Oct. 13

near a locker room at

Stone County High.

MISSOURI Charles: Police St. were looking for the man who stole a car, only to find out there was an infant in the back seat, KTVI-TV reported. The car was left a quarter-mile away. The child

was unharmed.

MONTANA Sheridan: Sheridan’s Ruby Valley Hospital and Medical Center is getting a new $13 million facility. The Montana Standard reported that the new branch will house a health care clinic, physical-therapy and radiology departments and three emergency rooms.

NEBRASKALincoln: Ultra-marathon runner Pete Kostelnick, 29, completed his San Francisco to New York City run across the USA, the Lincoln Journal Star reported. He finished in about 42 days, 6 hours and 30 minutes. That is an unofficial Guinness World Record for the fastest crossing of America on foot.

NEVADALas Vegas: Three people were arrested at gunpoint by Nevada Highway Patrol troopers after a chase of a suspected stolen car ended in a casino parking structure in northwestern Las Vegas, the Las Vegas Review-Journal reported.

NEW HAMPSHIRE Concord:

The state Fish and Game Department is seeking instructors to

teach ice

fishing, fly-fishing or basic fishing for its “Let’s Go Fishing” program. Registration is now open for the free training sessions that are required to become a certified instructor.

n u N c g t T o E r s

D

NEW JERSEY Cape May Point: A ship that towed warships to safety during World War II and battled 40-foot waves to help rescue seven people in what was portrayed in the book and film The Perfect Storm was poised to be sunk off the New Jersey and Delaware coasts. The Coast Guard vessel Tamaroa will help grow a reef by drawing large game fish and boosting recreational fishing. The sinking is planned for Sunday, the 25th anniversary of the 1991 storm in which the Tamaroa helped rescue the crew of a sailboat and a downed Air National Guard helicopter near Massachusetts.

NEW MEXICO Santa Fe: New Mexico employers could see a decrease in their insurance costs for on-the-job injuries and deaths. The state Office of Superintendent of Insurance says a key factor in calculating individual employers’ workers’ compensation costs will drop by an average of 9% in 2017.

NEW YORK Dix Hills: Gov. Cuomo announced the grand opening of a 15,000-square-foot welcome center located off the Long Island Expressway.

NORTH CAROLINA Charlotte: Duke Energy Carolinas is seeking 750,000 megawatt-hours of renewable energy to help the company meet a 2007 North Carolina law. The Charlotte-based utility is requesting bids from solar, wind, biomass, landfill gas and other facilities that qualify as a renewable energy resource, excluding swine and poultry waste.

NORTH DAKOTA Fort Yates: The U.S. Census Bureau canceled a planned field operations test next year on the Standing Rock Indian Reservation in the Dakotas due to funding concerns.

OHIO Toledo: The government of Cyprus is objecting to the Toledo Museum of Art’s sale of antiquities from the east Mediterranean island, The Blade reported. The museum also had pieces from Egypt, Greece and Italy among 68 being sold Tuesday in a New York auction.

OKLAHOMA Yukon: A forensic audit of Yukon’s finances in recent years turned up dozens of inaccuracies, many of which appear to be intentional acts of deception by former city manager Grayson Bottom, The Oklahoman reported.

OREGON Portland: Authorities suspended the search for Anna Schmidt, who has not been seen since Oct. 16.

PENNSYLVANIA Harrisburg: Classes resumed for more than 100,000 students who attend Pennsylvania’s 14 state-owned universities. The union representing more than 5,000 faculty members and coaches reached a tentative contract agreement Friday with the State System of Higher Education.

town RHODE : The ISLAND state fire South marshal Kings ’s - office is investigating two small fires over the weekend at the University of Rhode Island.

SOUTH CAROLINA Columbia: More than two weeks after Hurricane Matthew hit the state, more than 60 state roads and bridges are still closed because of storm damage and flooding.

SOUTH DAKOTA Chamberlain: Trial for a Kimball man accused of shooting a South Dakota Highway Patrol trooper nearly two years ago is being moved out of Brule County to better ensure an impartial jury, The Daily Republic reported.

TENNESSEE Nashville: Bloomberg Philanthropies and the Aspen Institute are leading a year-long effort with Nashville and nine other cities worldwide to prepare for the arrival of self-driving cars, The Tennessean reported.

TEXAS Dallas: Organizers said the just-completed State Fair of Texas attracted more than 2.4 million visitors. Officials said the 2016 State Fair of Texas generated more than $56 million in gross coupon sales for food, beverages and rides a record in the 130-year history of the event.

UTAH Salt Lake City: Police said a man died after his motorcycle collided with a pickup, KSL-TV reported.

VERMONT Burlington: The Burlington teachers union ratified a tentative employment agreement, possibly putting an end to 15 months of bitter negotiations over a one-year contract with the Burlington School Board, Burlington Free Press reported.

VIRGINIA Radford: Authorities said a man was shot with a blow dart near Radford University by someone who was driving by.

WASHINGTON Centralia: Authorities said a 19-year-old driver was killed and two passengers hurt after he lost control while speeding away from a police officer.

WEST VIRGINIA Dunbar: A father and his 5-year-old son have been injured after officials said a gas can exploded at a campfire, WSAZ-TV reported.

WISCONSIN Milwaukee: Farm and dairy groups are livid at Dannon, the world’s largest yogurt maker, for a pledge to source milk from cows that aren’t fed biotech grain, a move they say would dangerously turn the clock back on farming practices, Milwaukee Journal Sentinel reported. WYOMING Lander: A mountain lion was spotted recently in a residential area in the Wind River Mountain foothills, the Casper Star-Tribune reported.

by Compiled Tim Wendel from , staff with and Jonathan wire reports Briggs, Carolyn Mike Gottschamer Cerbin, Linda , Ben Dono Sheffler , , Matt Michael Young B. Smith . Design , Nichelle by Tiffany Smith Reusser and . Graphics by Janet Loehrke.

Title: Fort Smith moves against homeless by banning tent dwellings on private property
Full Text:
urn:contentItem:6775-S9K1-F03R-N0XR-00000-00Fort Smith moves against homeless by banning tent dwellings on private property2023-01-01T00:00:00Z2025-06-22T20:29:29ZLexisNexisFort Smith moves against homeless by banning tent dwellings on private property

Max Brantley

Jan 01, 2023( Arkansas Times: http://www.arktimes.com Delivered by Newstex)
The Northwest Arkansas Democrat-Gazette reports[1] that, beginning today, the city of Fort Smith is banning tents and camping equipment on private property without an owner's consent.


Said a city news release:
'We wish for all who dwell within the city limits to be safe, have adequate protection from weather and access to the required facilities for hygiene purposes. A tent does not meet the criteria of dwelling unit which is required to be connected to city water and sewer.'
Uh huh. This less about hygiene than rousting the homeless.
Good luck with that. From Monica Brich's article, quoting Chris Joannides, executive director of the Hope Campus, which serves homeless people:
'I am of the belief that the folks that stay outside will continue to stay outside, regardless of a 'tent ban'. This select group of folks will just move upstream again, so to speak, and stay out of the visual sights.'
It's a complicated issue, Joannides said. Indeed.
The post Fort Smith moves against homeless by banning tent dwellings on private property[2] appeared first on Arkansas Times[3].
[ 1]: https://www.nwaonline.com/news/2023/jan/01/unwanted-camping-on-private-property-banned/?utm_medium=social&utm_source=twitter_nwademgaz [ 2]: https://arktimes.com/arkansas-blog/2023/01/01/fort-smith-moves-against-homeless-by-banning-tent-dwellings-on-private-property [ 3]: https://arktimes.com

Title: TIF tiff: Downtown Little Rock Master Plan calls for controversial funding tool
Full Text:
urn:contentItem:6D0Y-XYF1-JCMN-Y1S4-00000-00TIF tiff: Downtown Little Rock Master Plan calls for controversial funding tool2024-09-20T00:00:00Z2025-06-22T20:29:29ZLexisNexisTIF tiff: Downtown Little Rock Master Plan calls for controversial funding tool

The Newstex Authoritative Content shall be construed as author-based content and commentary. Accordingly, no warranties or other guarantees are offered as to the quality of the opinions, commentary or anything else appearing in such Newstex Authoritative Content. Newstex and its re-distributors expressly reserve the right to delete stories at its and their sole discretion.

September 20th, 2024 (Arkansas Daily Weblog — Delivered by Newstex)

Imagine downtown Little Rock with more affordable housing, expanded public transportation and twice the number of people. All that, and more, is envisioned in the capital city's future in the comprehensive Downtown Little Rock Master Plan.

Drafted by the nonprofit Downtown Little Rock Partnership in collaboration with the design firm Sasaki and consulting firm SB Friedman, the comprehensive plan finalized in June aims to grow Little Rock's downtown population to be on par with those of similarly sized cities. It lays out strategies for making downtown more walkable, building more parks and trails, increasing access to the Arkansas River, and boosting tourism.

But invigorating downtown will require major investment, and the master plan would have some of that money come from taxpayers. One possible source of public funds is a one-cent sales tax proposed by Mayor Frank Scott Jr., which the Little Rock Board of Directors voted on July 30 to put on the November ballot. If Little Rock voters approve the increase, it would fund construction of  an indoor sports complex near the Clinton Presidential Center, among other projects. (The downtown master plan would absorb only a small part of  the proposed sales tax hike, which would also increase funding citywide for parks, infrastructure, the police and fire departments, and the Port of Little Rock.)

This rendering from the master plan shows potential areas for improvements or projects Credit: SASAKI

The plan says its single most important piece, though, is the creation of one or more 'tax increment financing' districts downtown. Tax increment financing, or TIF, is a complex financial policy tool that essentially allows local governments to divert revenue from future increases in property taxes in a specific geographic area and put that money toward development or public improvement projects in that same area. This is often done by issuing bonds to fund capital projects, then paying investors back over time.

'Most critical for the success of the entire plan is establishing tax increment financing (TIF) as a tool,' the plan says. The document advocates changing state laws and regulations to increase the amount of revenue a TIF district can capture. It even says city leaders should push for an amendment to the state constitution — which, if successful, could impact funding for public schools across Arkansas.

The city board approved the master plan on July 16, but that doesn't mean everything in it is a go. The plan is merely a list of suggestions, not a binding document. The city board would have to vote on creating a TIF district, and directors say they're still in the early stages of discussing next steps.

Ward 1 Director Virgil Miller told the Arkansas Times that Mayor Scott is planning to form a Downtown Master Plan implementation committee before the end of September. A spokesperson for the mayor did not respond to questions about Scott's plan to form an implementation committee, and neither the mayor nor city directors mentioned the master plan at the board's Sept. 17 meeting.

Ward 4 Director Capi Peck and Ward 5 Director Lance Hines both said they hadn't heard anything about master plan implementation since the board approved the plan in July. Peck also said first steps will likely depend on whether the sales tax passes in November. Another city director, who spoke to the Arkansas Times under the condition of anonymity, said the board is holding off on doing anything TIF-related until after the November election.

In the meantime, it's worth taking a closer look at what's in the master plan and how a TIF district would operate, if the board should eventually create one.

What is the master plan?

The new master plan could be seen as an attempt to undo the negative consequences of planning efforts in decades past. In the 1950s, '60s and '70s, the Central Little Rock Urban Renewal Project promised an end to slums and blight but instead  further segregated Little Rock's neighborhoods and made the city's infrastructure car-dependent, culminating with the opening of Interstate 630 in 1985 after two decades of construction.

'The subsequent results of that practice 50 years ago has created the built urban form that we know in downtown Little Rock,' said Daniel Church, associate planner at Sasaki. 'There's a lot of surface parking lots. It's a neighborhood that is largely geared toward driving in and out of with one-way streets. It's geared toward the automobile.'

While these conditions aren't the ideal starting place, the downtown area presents opportunities, Church said.

'You've got underutilized parking lots, which are a great opportunity for infill development. You've got the ability to reimagine streets for bikes and for people, more than just the automobile, and the opportunity to make one-way streets [into] two-way streets,' Church said.

Planners have been talking about making downtown more people-friendly for decades. The 1982 Downtown Little Rock Development Plan contained similar ideas to the new master plan, including improved public transportation, dedicated pedestrian paths to increase walkability and mixed-use development. The most tangible part of the 1982 plan to come to fruition was the creation of the River Market District.

The new master plan lists 44 strategies for transforming downtown. Some are focused on economic development: The master plan suggests building more housing and doubling the downtown population, currently about 4,400; establishing a 'Downtown Development Corporation' to manage new building and improvement projects; renovating underutilized buildings, like the Donaghey and Tower buildings, into mixed-use developments with affordable housing; and incentivizing the construction of a grocery store downtown. It proposes establishing a Black entrepreneurship and incubator hub on West Ninth Street to provide affordable space for start-ups.

This rendering from the master plan shows potential improvements and projects in the area surrounding Interstate 30. Credit: SASAKI

The master plan also includes ambitious proposals for improving transportation with a more efficient, high-frequency bus route; more bike lanes and wider sidewalks in certain areas; and an expansion of the trolley system to reach SoMa, the airport and Union Station. It suggests creating a connected trail network throughout downtown, developing new parks and public spaces, and closing the 'Dillard's Gap' in the Arkansas River Trail, a dangerous and confusing part of the multi-use trail near the Dillard's building that the city has tried to fix for more than 10 years.

Church and Gabe Holmstrom, executive director of the Downtown Little Rock Partnership, presented the plan to the Little Rock Board of Directors on July 2. The city board approved the plan July 16. But the real work is still ahead.

What is tax increment financing?

According to the plan's timeline, the first goal is to establish one or more TIF districts downtown, which would require further action from the city board.

TIF is a tool used by local governments to stimulate development in a specific geographic area by capturing a portion of property taxes in that area to pay for new public infrastructure or other projects. A local government can borrow against the captured tax revenue to finance development projects, with the expectation that it will eventually be able to pay off any loans in the coming years as projects are completed and the area improves. If all goes well, property values rise along with tax revenue, in a virtuous cycle of economic development.

Critics of TIF argue that it diverts money away from essential services like schools, while proponents argue that it is beneficial in the long run for school districts and other public services that depend on property taxes.

A TIF district will not take existing funding away from schools and other services; whatever baseline amount of property tax revenue the area generates at the time the district is created will continue to go toward those services. But as improvements are made in the TIF district and property values increase, the TIF district captures a portion of any increase in property tax revenue, diverting it away from the school district and other services. During the TIF district's lifespan, the diverted tax revenue goes toward financing bonds to pay for infrastructure in the TIF district.

After a TIF district expires — they last until the bonds issued for the district are paid off — schools and other local services will once again get the full amount of tax revenue from the area.

TIF districts in Arkansas are limited in what types of property tax revenue they can capture, making them a less powerful incentive here than they are in many states. State law keeps TIF districts from dipping too deeply into property taxes dedicated to public schools, for example.

TIF critics question whether it's necessary to divert funds at all to spur redevelopment.

Baker Kurrus, a former Little Rock School District superintendent and former school board member, said he's skeptical of TIF as a development tool. (Kurrus is a regular contributor to the Arkansas Times.)

'The way to get people to live [downtown] is to give the schools more money and say, 'You want to go to this area school? You have to live in the area,'' he said.

'There's no tax increment financing in the [Arkansas] cities that are growing at paces five, six times Little Rock's pace,' Kurrus said, pointing to fast-growing communities such as Benton and Bryant.

Church, the Sasaki planner, said LRSD will benefit from economic growth and will eventually see more money flowing into it than it ever would have without TIF.

'It [TIF] ultimately helps the school districts because it means that they're able to get development that is driving tax generation that's going into their coffers over time,' Church said. 'That wouldn't have happened otherwise.'

When Church and Holmstrom presented the master plan to the city board on July 2, Church recommended the board establish a TIF district, but also said there are lots of federal grants that could fund parts of the plan.

Holmstrom, the Downtown Little Rock Partnership director, told the Arkansas Times that the group is still 'researching some of the other economic development tools being used successfully in other states,' not just TIF. Regardless of the mechanism, Holmstrom said, some type of incentive is needed to stimulate new development downtown.

'All of these discussions are centered on concepts that will decrease the overall cost of development, which would help make projects [viable],' Holmstrom said. 'At the end of the day, [with] the increased cost of construction combined with current interest rates, the math does not work with our market rents. We need to figure out the best way to close that gap.'

What is TIF's track record in Arkansas?

TIF has been tried before in Arkansas, with mixed success.

Rockwater Village, a fast-growing residential development near the River Trail in North Little Rock, benefits from a TIF district, officially called the 'Lower Baring Cross Redevelopment District,' established in 2006. The developers behind Rockwater told Talk Business & Politics in 2023 that the area 'previously generated $58,874 in property taxes, if those could be collected. Now it generates more than $850,900.'

The North Little Rock School District has seen increases in its property tax collections from the area as Rockwater has grown, but it won't collect the full revenue until the TIF district expires. Bonds associated with the TIF district have final payments due on Dec. 1, 2031, according to the NLR city attorney's office. Records from the Pulaski County treasurer's office show the district captured about $209,000 in property tax revenue in 2023 to service the debt.

(Though the high property values in the area are generating more tax revenue for the school district, the newly constructed homes are far from affordable for most families in North Little Rock: A look at current Zillow.com prices for available Rockwater houses shows prices ranging from $500,000 to $785,000.)

Fayetteville's experience with tax increment financing has been less encouraging than North Little Rock's. In 2005, the city of Fayetteville created a 350-acre TIF district downtown, issued $3.7 million in bonds to fund the demolition of a blighted building, and approved the construction of a hotel in its place. Planners expected the assessed value of properties in the district would reach $95 million by 2011 and predicted the bonds would be paid off by 2029 with the tax revenue generated by the hotel.

By 2011, the construction plans had fallen apart, in part due to the 2008 financial crisis. Property values within the district were assessed at only $47.2 million, the Northwest Arkansas Democrat-Gazette reported that year. A parking lot was eventually built over the demolition site, and  the would-be developers paid the city $300,000 in damages for not following through on their plans. The ordeal left Fayetteville taxpayers with millions of dollars in bonds to pay off on a much longer timeline than predicted

In 2013, Little Rock established a TIF district near Otter Creek Road and the I-430 and I-30 interchange to incentivize development of the Bass Pro Shop and an outlet mall.

The city has one other active TIF district in the Port of Little Rock, the industrial area southeast of the airport. Established in 2004, the 'Port of Little Rock Redevelopment District No. 2' funded infrastructure to prepare the area for private industrial development.

Though Rockwater and Otter Creek have experienced rapid growth, skeptics of TIF districts question whether they're a necessary perk to prod redevelopment or simply a giveaway for developers. In Little Rock, areas such as Pettaway and SoMa have seen much development in recent years without TIF districts.

The midtown area of Little Rock near Park Plaza Mall is another example of redevelopment without TIF. In 2003, the city board created the Midtown Redevelopment District and approved the creation of a TIF district. It was never established, though, and the board disbanded the redevelopment district in 2020. As Max Brantley noted in a  2020 Arkansas Times article, private developers have invested millions of dollars in the area since 2003 without the incentive of a TIF district.

The master plan calls for changing state law. Why?

TIF districts aren't as widely used in Arkansas as elsewhere, partly due to Arkansas's tax structure. The state's property tax rates are among the lowest in the country and its sales tax rates are among the highest. And because Arkansas has declared some shares of property tax off limits, TIF captures less revenue here than it would in most states.

Arkansas property taxes are measured in mills, or one-tenth of a cent. A mill generates one dollar in tax revenue for every $1,000 of assessed property value. The millage rate in Little Rock is now 70.5, of which 46.4 mills go to the Little Rock School District and the rest goes to the city and county.

The LRSD's share includes a special 25-mill minimum tax that is levied in every school district in Arkansas. The state pools the funds from those 25 mills and redistributes it among Arkansas's school districts. In 2007, the state Supreme Court ruled that TIF districts aren't allowed to touch those 25 mills. The decision 'effectively gutted TIF,' according to a 2020 article in the University of Arkansas at Little Rock Law Review.

Arkansas law also restricts TIF districts from taking any mills dedicated to libraries, fire and police pension funds, county hospitals or servicing bonds that existed before the TIF district was established.

Not only are TIF districts in Arkansas limited in how much revenue they can tap into, they're also restricted in how they can spend it. Current Arkansas law requires TIF to be used only for public improvements, like roads and parks, rather than directly incentivizing private development.

Church said Arkansas is 'way behind' almost every other state in terms of 'what millage can be captured and be used for TIF.'

But changing the most important piece of the law as it stands now — the fact that the 25 mills are off limits to TIF districts — would require a constitutional amendment or a new ruling by the Supreme Court.

The Downtown Little Rock Master Plan suggests city officials lobby the state Legislature both for changes to statutory law and a constitutional amendment, which would ultimately require voter approval.

'The most critical amendments to state TIF law are: 1) expanding the total millage that can be collected by the TIF, and 2) expanding the range of eligible uses for TIF funding beyond those related to public infrastructure, including land acquisition, property assembly, site preparation, and other private development costs,' the plan reads.

Kurrus, the public school advocate, criticized the idea of changing state law to allow TIF to capture property tax revenue allotted for schools. 'If you want to throttle back the amount of money a school district has to work with by taking some of that [revenue] away, you're not going to have an urban area that's attractive to middle-class families and children,' he said.

No matter what the master plan says, it isn't yet clear if the Downtown Little Rock Partnership and city officials will pursue that route. Kyle Leyenberger, communications director of the Downtown Little Rock Partnership, said everything is up in the air at this point.

In July, as the city board was preparing to vote on the master plan, Mayor Scott said it would take at least a year or two for a constitutional amendment changing TIF law to go before voters.

'I don't think we want to wait on something that we can't determine for another year-and-a-half, two years,' Scott said at the July 9 city board meeting.

A spokesperson for Scott did not respond when asked about the mayor's position on the TIF portion of the master plan.

At the moment, the mayor is more focused on passing the one-cent sales tax this November, which would also fund parts of the master plan. The tax would spend millions on parks, public safety, public infrastructure and the Port of Little Rock. Made up of a five-eighths-cent general capital purposes tax, which would last 10 years, and a permanent three-eighths-cent tax for general operational purposes, the city estimates the tax would bring in $650 million over the next decade.

Since the city board voted to send the tax to voters, Scott has been encouraging residents to vote in favor of the tax at nearly all of his public appearances.

Title: 'Stateswomen': Talk scheduled Tuesday on book about Arkansas women legislators
Full Text:
urn:contentItem:66VV-2K01-F03R-N43Y-00000-00'Stateswomen': Talk scheduled Tuesday on book about Arkansas women legislators2022-11-14T00:00:00Z2025-06-22T20:29:36ZLexisNexis'Stateswomen': Talk scheduled Tuesday on book about Arkansas women legislators

Newstex and its re-distributors expressly reserve the right to delete stories at its and their sole discretion.

Max Brantley

Nov 14, 2022( Arkansas Daily Weblog: https://arktimes.com/arkansas-blog Delivered by Newstex)
Lindsley Armstrong SmithandStephen A. Smith, authors of 'Stateswomen: A Centennial History of Arkansas Women Legislators, 1922-2022' will talk about their book at 6 p.m. Tuesday at the Clinton Presidential Center
The book marks a century of service by women in the Arkansas General Assembly -146 of them. Jay Barth, director of the Clinton Library, will moderate the conversation and a book signing will follow.


Advertisement
The program is free. It also will be streamed live by the Clinton Center.
Click here to register.[1]
Advertisement
The Smiths, who married in 1994, are both former legislators and University of Arkansas faculty members.
A UA Press promotional release[2] for the book says:
Advertisement
Stateswomenshines a light on the women who have served as some of the state's central decision makers. Drawing on documentary research and oral histories, Lindsley Armstrong Smith and Stephen A. Smith present lively, concise biographies for the nearly 150 women legislators who have served in the general assembly to date, chronicling their personal histories, volunteer work and social activism, and legislative victories. In a probing introduction, the authors examine the neglected role of women in Arkansas political history alongside the 'long history of resistance to full citizenship rights for women in Arkansas'—demonstrating that political representation is essential for improving opportunities in the wider society.
The first comprehensive study dedicated to these trailblazing Arkansas legislators,Stateswomenwill surely inspire history buffs, community-minded citizens, and political hopefuls alike.
I can testify that the Smiths are not stuffy academics.
The Encyclopedia of Arkansas's account[3] of Lindsley Smith's legislative efforts is, I'm sorry to say, something of a benchmark of the reversal of political tides at the General Assembly.
Smith's first bill expanded coverage of the Workers Compensation Act to include work-related neck injuries that had been previously excluded (Act 1250 of 2005). Her major legislative accomplishments included two measures intended to enhance citizen participation in government and public affairs by protecting citizens exercising First Amendment rights from frivolous strategic lawsuits against public participation (Act 1843 of 2005) and awarding expenses to citizens who prevail inFreedom of Information Act[4]enforcement litigation (Act 440 of 2009). Onenvironmental[5]issues, she sponsored legislation expanding the Arkansas Wetlands Mitigation Bank (Act 476 of 2007), requiring utility net metering provisions for renewable energy sources (Act 1026 of 2007), and establishing the Heritage Trails System (Act 728 of 2009). Smith sponsored several bills to protect victims of domestic violence (Act 1875 of 2005, Act 682 of 2007, and Act 619 of 2009), as well as protecting women's health by requiring health insurance policies to cover prescriptions forcontraceptives[6](Act 2217 of 2005) and requiring employers to provide unpaid break time and reasonable locations for expressing breast milk (Act 621 of 2009).
Appropriation measures to benefit citizens of Fayetteville sponsored by Smith included bills providing General Improvement Funds forKUAF Public Radio[7], the UA Diane D. Blair Center of Southern Politics & Society, the Special Collections Department of UA Mullins Library, the UA Pryor Center for Arkansas Oral and Visual History, Seven Hills Homeless Shelter, Fayetteville Scull Creek Trail, Fayetteville Fine Arts Festival, Peace at Home Family Shelter, Ozark Guidance Center, Single Parent Scholarship Fund, and the Fayetteville Public Library.
Among other legislative efforts that Smith considered significant were her unsuccessful attempt to addsexual orientation[8]to the classes protected by theArkansas Civil Rights Act[9](HB 2751, 2005) and her sponsorship of the unsuccessful effort to secure ratification of theEqual Rights Amendment[10]to the U.S. Constitution in 2005, 2007, and 2009.
Stephen Smith has quite a record, too, legislatively and elsewhere.[11]
[ 1]: https://forms.clinton-foundation.org/view.php?id=812775 [ 2]: https://search.uark.edu/s/redirect?collection=uark-news-search&url=https%3A%2F%2Fnews.uark.edu%2Farticles%2F62555%2Flindsley-armstrong-smith-and-stephen-a-smith-publish-new-book-on-arkansas-women-legislators&auth=lp7IxmP%2BQYg0LjbYRhQWcQ&profile=_default&rank=1&query=lindsley+smith [ 3]: https://encyclopediaofarkansas.net/entries/lindsley-farrar-armstrong-smith-15321/ [ 4]: https://encyclopediaofarkansas.net/entries/Arkansas-Freedom-of-Information-Act-4599 [ 5]: https://encyclopediaofarkansas.net/entries/Environment-390 [ 6]: https://encyclopediaofarkansas.net/entries/Birth-Control-Movement-6460 [ 7]: https://encyclopediaofarkansas.net/entries/KUAF-13766 [ 8]: https://encyclopediaofarkansas.net/entries/Gay-and-Lesbian-Movement-1177 [ 9]: https://encyclopediaofarkansas.net/entries/Arkansas-Civil-Rights-Act-of-1993-7312 [ 10]: https://encyclopediaofarkansas.net/entries/Equal-Rights-Amendment-13669 [ 11]: https://encyclopediaofarkansas.net/entries/stephen-austin-smith-17998/

Title: Best of Arkansas 2021
Full Text:
urn:contentItem:638X-T361-F03R-N2XV-00000-00Best of Arkansas 20212021-08-02T00:00:00Z2025-06-22T20:29:41ZLexisNexisBest of Arkansas 2021Arkansas Times Staff

Aug 02, 2021( Arkansas Daily Weblog: https://arktimes.com/arkansas-blog Delivered by Newstex)
Bitching and moaning is what we do best at the Arkansas Times lately, but sometimes you have to don rose-colored sunglasses and cheer yourself up with a trip to the snow cone shack. Even the most entrenched misanthropes among us can admit there are some fine people doing delightful things around here (shout out to Arkansas's 2021 best budtender, Buffy Montgomery!), and that perhaps that's cause enough to keep putting one foot in front of the other. Arkansas's pathetic vaccination rates could suck anyone into the doldrums, but the annual Best of Arkansas edition is a well-timed shot in the arm.


The readers have voted, and you have pretty good taste. Sen. Joyce Elliott is indeed the best Arkansan. The Van, which supported the dignity of our homeless population even through the pandemic by helping them secure essentials like clothes, food and toothpaste, deserves accolades and support. Discovery's reign as the best gay bar should not and has not been challenged.
Advertisement
We peppered some of the winners with lightning round Q&As, and were happy we did. Actress Jamee McAdoo shared what it's like to dip a toe into the pageant scene and wind up winning the tiara. Designer Kelley Kolletis tipped us off to the color of the year and even told us how to not mess it up. TV meteorologist Todd Yakoubian offered up a dad joke tragic and endearing enough to make the whole state groan.
The editors here have favorites, too, and we took the liberty of fleshing out readers' nominations with a few of our own. Food editor (and best author nominee) Rhett Brinkley picked Arkansas's best peck of pickles on a road trip to visit Blytheville's own Mr. Davis Pickles. A former preschool teacher who bounded into the pickle-making arena after sampling his own mother's recipe and finding it wanting (savage!), Dedric Davis pickles whatever he pleases, rules be damned. Turkey bologna? Hot dogs? Sure, pickle them, why not? And his cucumber-based concoctions are equally innovative. Can't decide between dill or bread and butter? Let Mr. Davis Pickles blow your mind with a combination of the two flavors, all in one jar.
Advertisement
Our most elusive editor, Lindsey Millar, gives up the secret location of his clubhouse with a story about Natural State Treehouses, a Fayetteville-based business that can make your childhood dreams come true.
And culture editor Stephanie Smittle combines encyclopedic knowledge of the Little Rock music scene and her signature balletic prose to remind us why the White Water Tavern, our favorite phoenix, will always rise to the top of any best live music venue list.
Advertisement
The mosquitoes are biting and a dark virus cloud seems to have settled over the state like we're the Addams Family or something. But if it's the end times, might as well enjoy them. So binge watch 'The Mysterious Benedict Society' courtesy of Little Rock's best newly famous writer, Trenton Lee Stewart. Affix some faux lashes from Beauty & Beyond to look your most fly on the voyage to the hereafter. Drop in at Colonial Wines and Spirits ('best booze to go') and provision yourself to offer up a proper farewell toast. It's summer vacation's (and maybe even Western civilization's) last gasp. Let's break out the good stuff.
Make your next pickle your best pickle with Mr. Davis Pickles[1] Meet the cucumber king of Blytheville. by Rhett Brinkley
Wigging out[2] Beauty & Beyond is a cosmetological wonderland. by Austin Bailey
Change of the guard: White Water Tavern reopens under new ownership[3] Same White Water Tavern, but slightly cleaner. by Stephanie Smittle
Advertisement
Natural State Treehouses makes dreams come true[4] Fayetteville contractor Josh Hart is riding high during a treehouse boom. by Lindsey Millar
Trenton Lee Stewart's 'The Mysterious Benedict Society' is an enterprise in emotional memory[5] The Little Rock author, whose beloved middle-grade novels spawned a new 'Disney Plus' adaptation, specializes in riddles, puzzles, mazes and daydreams. By Jordan Hickey

The No Cruising signs were removed after a vote in 2011 by the Silver Lake Neighborhood Council, and some of the no U-turn signs have remained up since.

Meloni Has 'Abortion' Removed From G7 Statement

Italian Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni appeared to have successfully quashed an element of a contentious G7 statement by removing the word 'abortion' from the group's final text at this year's meeting of the organisation's leaders.

The move appeared designed to defuse an issue that risked distracting from the high-profile summit she is hosting in her home country.

Italy holds the current G7 presidency and Meloni is presiding over the June 13-15 G7 gathering of heads of the world's largest economies in Italy's southern city of Bari.

A senior Italian diplomat confirmed to Reuters the word 'abortion' would not appear in the final communique.

Police Investigate After Truck Driver Does 'Burnout' on West Virginia Pride Crosswalk

Police in Huntington, West Virginia are investigating skid marks that were left on a Pride crosswalk on the street. After an LGBTQ organization painted the colors on the street, a truck peeled out the left the marks on the rainbow-colored street painting. Now police are investigating.

According to a report from Eyewitness News, police in Huntington have begun looking into the case and are 'investigating the circumstances.' The driver in the truck did a burn out, leaving marks and creating a cloud of smoke.

UK: 'Grand Tour' Presenter Stands Ground After Calling Rows of Pride Flags 'Oppressive'

Authored by Steve Watson via Modernity.news

British TV presenter James May, most famous for being a part of motoring shows The Grand Tour and Top Gear with Jeremy Clarkson, is under fire for pointing out that the uniform rows and rows of Pride flags installed every year in central London look 'oppressive.'

May made what was supposed to be a tongue in cheek comment on X, noting that while he has 'observed and admired' the Pride movement for years, the recent displays are guilty of 'Too Much Bunting,' which 'may be seen as authoritarian, and therefore oppressive.'

May added, ' Please remember that some terrible things, with which you would not wish to be allied, began with TMB. World War Two, for example. Nice flag, though.'

Link to the original story.

Title: Gates of Vienna News Feed 4/6/2024
Full Text:
